variant.question: A controlled flight operating under IFR passes a designated compulsory reporting point on the routeIn accordance with ICAO Annex 2, Rules of the Air, the pilot shall report to Air Traffic Control the

options.text: time and level.
time, heading and level, and verify the route to the next reporting point.
heading and level, and verify the route to the next reporting point.
time and heading.

variant.question: If an IFR flight operated in IMC in a controlled airspace, where radar is not used in the provision of air traffic control, encounters a communication failure, it shall maintain the last assigned

options.text: speed and level for a period of 20 minutes and thereafter adjust level and speed in accordance with the filed flight plan.
speed and level for a period of 10 minutes and thereafter descend in VMC and continue the flight to the nearest suitable aerodrome.
level for a period of 5 minutes and thereafter continue in accordance with the filed flight plan.
speed and level for a period of 10 minutes and thereafter descend and land at the nearest suitable aerodrome.

variant.question: An aircraft experiences radio communication failure on an IFR flight in IMC. It shall land, If possible, within:

options.text: 30 minutes after the ETA or the last acknowledged Expected Approach Time, whichever is later.
10 minutes after the ETA or the last acknowledged Expected Approach Time, whichever is later.
15 minutes after crossing the designated navigation fix from which a normal Instrument approach can be conducted.
15 minutes of the ETA as stated in the current IF flight plan, or hold at a designated navigation fix.

variant.question: Whilst flying in an aerodrome's traffic circuit, an aircraft receives a series of green flashes from the tower. The aircraft:

options.text: must come back to land or continue the approach and the landing clearance will be sent in due time.
is cleared to land.
must land immediately and clear the landing area.
must give way to another aircraft.

variant.question: Refer to Dubrovnik Chart 10-9 from Jeppesen GSPRM 2017. You are flying a Cat C A320, which initial magnetic track do you follow after CAVTAT NDB?

options.text: 158º
115º
295º
148º

variant.question: A radar controller issues the following instruction to an aircraft'FLY HEADING 030'The pilot must fly heading

options.text: 030° magnetic.
030° true.
030° magnetic in still air conditions (thereby flying the magnetic track).
030° true, in still air conditions (thereby flying the true track).

variant.question: The aircraft has made a complete stop on the apronWhen leaving the aircraft, one of the passengers walks into the trailing edge of the wing and gets seriously injuredWhat is this and what reporting procedure must be followed?

options.text: An accident and the crew must follow the procedure relevant to this case.
An incident and the pilot-in-command must report it to the airport authority within 48 hours.
A matter of passenger insurance and the airport operator or the company in charge of the handling shall write a report for the insurance company.
An irregularity in passenger handling and the handling agent must inform their insurance company.

variant.question: You are on an IFR flight in airspace where radar is NOT used in the provision of air traffic control. You are experiencing a complete radio failure and were unable to report your position at the last compulsory reporting point. You shall maintain the last assigned speed and level, or minimum flight altitude if higher, for a period of how long after failing to report your position over the compulsory reporting point?

options.text: 20 minutes
15 minutes
30 minutes
25 minutes

variant.question: The inbound magnetic track for holding is 052, turns are to the right, and the outbound time is 1 minute. – The appropriate entry procedure for a flight on magnetic track 232 with no wind is..

options.text: either offset or parallel.
offset only.
either parallel or direct.
direct only.

variant.question: When is a time check required?

options.text: Before a controlled flight and at any such time during flight as may be necessary.
From ATC only before a controlled flight.
After take-off but before the first position report.
Before any flight

variant.question:
What should be advised by ATC to the pilot prior to taxi if no information has been received before?
1. Runway in use 
 2. Visibility or RVR whatever is applicable 
 3. Surface wind 
 4. Transition level 
 5. For turbo-engined aircraft - temperature at the runway to be used 
 6. QNH 
 7. Expected time of departure 
 8. Correct time.
An Aerodrome Control Tower shall report to the Area Control Centre if an aircraft fails to land within:

options.text: 5 minutes after the expected landing time.
15 minutes after the expected approach time.
5 minutes after the expected approach time.
15 minutes after the expected landing time.

variant.question: When a RADAR operator says the following to an aircraft: "fly heading 030", the pilot must fly heading:

options.text: 030° magnetic
030° magnetic in still air conditions (thereby flying the magnetic track)
030° true, in still air conditions (thereby flying the true track)
030° true

variant.question: What Information is to be passed by ATC before taxi

options.text: Time, Temperature, QNH, Runway in use, Wind, Visibility(if less than 10KM)
Time, Temperature, QNH, Runway in use, Wind, Visibility
Time, Temperature, QNH, Runway in use, Visibility(if less than 10KM)
Temperature, QNH, Runway in use, Wind, Visibility(if less than 10KM)

variant.question: If no information has been received, what information is given to an aircraft on its first call to Tower prior to taxi?

options.text: Runway in use, wind, QNH and visibility below 10 km.
Runway in use, QNH and visibility below 10 km.
Runway in use, wind, QNH and Transition Level.
Runway in use, wind, QNH, visibility below 10 km, Transition Level and time.

variant.question: The tower has issued a landing clearence to an aircraft on short final. Who should the tower controller alert and when if the aircraft has not landed?

options.text: Sound the crash alarm and inform rescue services after 5 min.
Sound the crash alarm and inform rescue services after 20 min.
Advise area controller after 5 min.
Advise area controller after 20 min.

variant.question: A pilot recognizes that he/she does not have enough enough final reserve fuel. The aircraft 40 minutes away from the departure (A) and 50 minutes to the destination (B). There is a runway of another aerodrome (C) in sight but ATC reports that the weather is below minimum. What should the pilot do?

options.text: Land at C.
Continue to B.
Return to A.
Declare an emergency and ask ATC for further instructions.

variant.question: During the climb-out phase of a flight, the pilot-in-command becomes incapacitated. The co-pilot takes control of the aircraft and returns it safely to the aerodrome of departure. What notification or reporting action must be taken after landing?

options.text: The crew must follow the procedure relevant to an incident.
The pilot-in-command or the operator must complete a report on behalf of the airport authority within 48 hours.
The operator must inform the airport authority by writing an irregularity report.
The crew must follow the procedure relevant to an accident.
